hints_latex:

integration. Often it is very helpful to make a sketch, like this
(boundaries of the region are in red):

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH200/December_2011/Math200Dec11Q7.jpg}
hints_raw:
The hardest part here is to find the boundaries for the region of integration. Often it is very helpful to make a sketch, like this (boundaries of the region are in red):

[[File:Math200Dec11Q7.jpg|400px|Sketch of the region of integration, the boundaries of the region are in red]]
sols_html:
The plane \(\displaystyle z+y = 1\) intesects \(\displaystyle z=0\) at the line \(\displaystyle y=1, z=0\). Since the region is is the first octant, we know that \(\displaystyle x,y,z\geq 0\).

Using this information and the sketch in the hint, we find the region \(\displaystyle E\) as \(\displaystyle E=\{(x,y,z)\in\R^3|\ 0\leq z\leq 1-y,\ x^2\leq y\leq 1,\ 0\leq x\leq 1\}\)

Hence the integral is

\[\begin{aligned} \iiint_E x\;\text{d}V &= \int_0^1\int_{x^2}^1\int_{0}^{1-y}x\;\text{d}z\text{d}y\text{d}x\\ &= \int_0^1\int_{x^2}^1x(1-y)\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\\ &= \int_0^1 x\left[y-\frac{y^2}{2}\right]_{x^2}^1\;\text{d}x\\ &= \int_0^1 \frac{x}{2} - x^3 + \frac{x^5}{2}\;\text{d}x\\ &=\left[\frac{x^2}{4} - \frac{x^4}{4} + \frac{x^6}{12}\right]_0^1 = \frac{1}{12}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
The plane $\displaystyle z+y = 1$ intesects $\displaystyle z=0$ at the
line $\displaystyle y=1, z=0$. Since the region is is the first octant,
we know that $\displaystyle x,y,z\geq 0$.

Using this information and the sketch in the hint, we find the region
$\displaystyle E$ as
$\displaystyle E=\{(x,y,z)\in\R^3|\ 0\leq z\leq 1-y,\ x^2\leq y\leq 1,\ 0\leq x\leq 1\}$

Hence the integral is

\begin{align*}
\iiint_E x\;\text{d}V &= \int_0^1\int_{x^2}^1\int_{0}^{1-y}x\;\text{d}z\text{d}y\text{d}x\\
&= \int_0^1\int_{x^2}^1x(1-y)\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\\
&= \int_0^1 x\left[y-\frac{y^2}{2}\right]_{x^2}^1\;\text{d}x\\
&= \int_0^1 \frac{x}{2} - x^3 + \frac{x^5}{2}\;\text{d}x\\
&=\left[\frac{x^2}{4} - \frac{x^4}{4} + \frac{x^6}{12}\right]_0^1 = \frac{1}{12}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
The plane <math> \displaystyle z+y = 1</math> intesects <math> \displaystyle z=0 </math> at the line <math> \displaystyle y=1, z=0 </math>. Since the region is is the first octant, we know that <math> \displaystyle x,y,z\geq 0</math>.

Using this information and the sketch in the hint, we find the region <math> \displaystyle E </math> as
<math> \displaystyle E=\{(x,y,z)\in\R^3|\ 0\leq z\leq 1-y,\ x^2\leq y\leq 1,\ 0\leq x\leq 1\}</math>



Hence the integral is

<math> \displaystyle \begin{align}
\iiint_E x\;\text{d}V &= \int_0^1\int_{x^2}^1\int_{0}^{1-y}x\;\text{d}z\text{d}y\text{d}x\\
&= \int_0^1\int_{x^2}^1x(1-y)\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\\
&= \int_0^1 x\left[y-\frac{y^2}{2}\right]_{x^2}^1\;\text{d}x\\
&= \int_0^1 \frac{x}{2} - x^3 + \frac{x^5}{2}\;\text{d}x\\
=&\left[\frac{x^2}{4} - \frac{x^4}{4} + \frac{x^6}{12}\right]_0^1 = \frac{1}{12}
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
Evaluate the triple integral

\[\begin{aligned} \iiint_{E}x\,dV,\end{aligned}\]

where E is the region in the first octant bounded by the parabolic cylinder \(\displaystyle y = x^{2}\) and the planes \(y + z = 1,\,x = 0,\,z = 0\).
statement_latex:
Evaluate the triple integral

\begin{align*}
\iiint_{E}x\,dV,
\end{align*} where E is the region in the first octant bounded
by the parabolic cylinder $\displaystyle y = x^{2}$ and the planes
$y + z = 1,\,x = 0,\,z = 0$.
statement_raw:
Evaluate the triple integral 
:<math>\iiint_{E}x\,dV </math>, 
where E is the region in the first octant bounded by the parabolic cylinder <math>\displaystyle y = x^{2}</math> and the planes <math>y + z = 1,\,x = 0,\,z = 0</math>.
